Yes, hops can have a significant impact on the flavor, aroma, and bitterness of beer. They are used primarily as a bittering agent to balance out the sweetness of the malt, but they can also contribute a range of other flavors and aromas depending on how they're used.

Here are some examples of different flavors hops can contribute to beer:

1. Bitterness: As you mentioned, hops are commonly used to add bitterness to beer. This is because they contain alpha acids, which are extracted during the boiling process and then create a bitter flavor when added to the beer. The bitterness of the beer can be adjusted by adding more or less hops.

2. Floral and citrus flavors: Some types of hops, such as Cascade and Centennial, are known for their floral and citrusy flavors. These hops are often used in American-style pale ales and IPAs to add a bright, refreshing character to the beer.

3. Piney and herbal flavors: Other varieties, like Chinook and Columbus, can have a more earthy, piney, or herbal flavor. These are often used in darker, maltier beers or in West Coast-style IPAs to balance out the sweetness and add complexity.

4. Spicy and fruity flavors: Some hops, like Saaz and Tettnang, have a spicy, herbal, or even fruity flavor. These hops are often used in lighter, more delicate beers like pilsners and wheat beers.

The way the hops are added to the beer can also affect their flavor. For example, hops that are added early in the boiling process will contribute more bitterness, while hops added towards the end of the boil or during fermentation will contribute more aroma and flavor.

Overall, hops are a versatile ingredient that can add a range of complex flavors and aromas to beer, in addition to their role in balancing out the sweetness from the malt.
